English_Definition: Consumable expendable inputs in agricultural production for both crops and livestock, for example fertilisers, seeds, veterinary drugs, etc.
Crops that are planted and harvested during the same production season.
Sesotho: Dijalo tsa selemo tsa hang ka selemo

English_Definition: Area harvested for dry grain (whole grain, seed, beans or unshelled nuts) for commercial purposes, or to be retained for seed, animal feed or human consumption. It therefore excludes areas planted but not harvested owing to hail damage, fire, grazing, etc., and areas harvested but not used for grain, but for silage, etc.
Sepedi: Palomoka ya tema ya puno ya leroro

English_Definition: That part of the total area planted that is planted with the intention of harvesting it for grain rather than for silage, grazing or fodder.
Sepedi: Tema ye e lemetšwego leroro/tema ye e lemetšwego dijothoro

English_Definition: Crop grown for sale rather than for consumption on the farm. Synonym is food crop.
Wheat, coarse grains and rice.
A farm producing agricultural products intended for the market, usually registered for value added tax (VAT) and income tax.
Sesotho: Polasi ya kgwebo; polasi ya ho hweba

English_Definition: A person who produces agricultural products intended for the market. See subsistence farmer.
Quantitative determination of crop yield after harvest.
Sesotho: Dipalopalo tsa tekanyetso ya kotulo; kakanyo ya kotulo

English_Definition: Quantitative approximation of the crop yield prepared and released before harvest.
Sesotho: Dipalopalo tse lebeletsweng tsa kotulo; ditebello tsa kotulo

English_Definition: Livestock for breeding (including fish and poultry), dairy, draught, etc. and vineyards, orchards and other plantations of trees yielding repeat products that are under the direct management of the institutional units.
Sepedi: Dithoto tša temo tše di bušeletšago tšweletšo

English_Definition: Irrigation practice which minimises the use of water and fertiliser by allowing water to drop slowly to the roots of plants, either onto the soil surface, or directly to the root zone, through a network of valves, pipes, tubing and emitters.
Person trained in agriculture and employed by the Department of Agriculture or any other body responsible for rendering assistance to farmers to promote good farming practices.
An area of land, together with its buildings, concerned with the growing of crops or the raising of animals.

One or more farms, smallholdings or pieces of land, whether adjacent or not, operated as a single unit and situated within the same magisterial district or province, on which cultivation is carried out for both commercial and non-commercial purposes, in the open air or under cover. It includes land rented from others, the farmstead and other buildings, cropland, pasture, veld, wasteland and dams, but excludes land leased to others. A farming unit could be owned by a single person, partnership, company, or close corporation, etc.
Irrigation practice that spreads water from open field ditches and other conveyance systems.
IsiXhosa: unkcenkceshelo ngokuvulela amanzi azihambele / unkcenkceshelo ngokuvulela isikhukhula samanzi

English_Definition: See cash crop.
Harvested produce of cereals, pulses, oil crops and legumes.
Grain actually removed from the field.
Sesotho: Dijothollo tse kotutsweng; tlhahiso ya dijothollo

English_Definition: Metric unit of land measurement equivalent to 10 000 square metres.
A substance / mixture of substances used to kill plants that are not wanted in a specific area. Synonym: weedkiller
Any crop that provides material for industrial processes and products. Examples: cotton, flax, linen, etc.; tobacco; oilseeds such as sunflower, and beverages such as tea and coffee.
IsiXhosa: izityalo ezingaveliselwa kutya, izityalo zemizi mveliso, izityalo ezithi zisetyenzwe phambi kokuba zibenokusetyenziswa

English_Definition: A crop planted between rows of another crop.
Artificial application of water to land to assist in the growing of crops and pastures.
All animals or birds kept or reared mainly for agricultural purposes including cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, horses, poultry, rabbits, etc.
Forest tree that grows in its natural habitat.
A survey based on actual counts and measurements made in the field.
Sesotho: Patlisiso e lekantsweng ya tlhahiso; dipatlisiso tse akaretsang tsa tlhahiso

English_Definition: Annual plant whose seeds or fruit are used mainly for extraction of culinary and industrial oils.
Sesotho: Sejalo se hlahisang oli; dijalo tsa oli

English_Definition: Dry seeds harvested from annual oil-bearing crops used for food, feed, seed or industrial purposes.
Crops that are not replanted after each harvest.
A substance / mixture of substances used to kill pests.
Trees that are planted by the holder on the holding, e.g. eucalyptus trees. See natural forest tree.
Sepedi: Dithokgwa tša go bjalwa/mehlare ya pholantheišene

English_Definition: An annual leguminous plant yielding seeds used for food, feed, seed, and industrial purposes.
Sesotho: Dijalo tsa peo ya dikgaketla; monawa

English_Definition: A system of agriculture or agricultural production in which a landowner allows a tenant to use the land in return for a share of the crop produced on the land.
A survey based on information obtained from farmers about their fields based on opinion or experience.
Sesotho: Patlisiso ya tlhahiso ka ditsebi; dipatlisiso tsa tlhahiso ka botsebi

English_Definition: A person who produces crops primarily for own consumption.
See drip irrigation.
See herbicide.
Amount of product harvested per unit area.
Yield from the area actually harvested.
IsiXhosa: Imveliso yommandla ovuniweyo/ isivuno saloo ndawo
Sepedi: Puno go tšwa temeng ye e bunnwego
Sesotho: Hlahiso ya serapa se kotutsweng; tjhai ya tshimo ka nngwe e kotutsweng
Setswana: Thobo ka kgaolo e e kotutsweng
Xitsonga: Ntshovelo ku ya hi ndhawu leyi tshoveriweke

English_Definition: Yield from the area planted.
IsiXhosa: Imveliso yommandla otyaliweyo/ isivuno sendawo etyaliweyo
Sepedi: Puno go tšwa temeng ye e lemilwego
Sesotho: Tlhahiso ya serapa se lenngweng; tjhai ya tshimo ka nngwe e jetsweng
Setswana: Thobo ka kgaolo e e jwetsweng
Xitsonga: Ntshovelo ku ya hi ndhawu leyi rimiweke

English_Definition: An amount of money, usually linked to the quantity of the goods or services sold, paid to sales persons.
IsiXhosa: ikhomishini, ucuntsu wemali enikezwa abo bancedisa umnini weshishini athengise iimpahla zakhe

English_Definition: An enterprise, or part of an enterprise, which is situated at a single location in which only a single productive activity is carried out or in which the principal productive activity accounts for most of the value added.
Sepedi: Sehlongwa sa kgwebo / Setheo sa kgwebo

English_Definition: Tax levied on the financial income of a person, cooperation or other legal entity.
An area that predominantly has industry as its main land use.
Excess of expenditure over sales revenue.
IsiZulu: Imali elahleke ngqo / Imali ecwile ngqo

English_Definition: Excess of sales revenue over the cost of production.
A place of business for retailing goods / services. Examples: shop, market, service establishment, or other place, where goods and / or services are sold.
A freestanding property / house in a complex with a common boundary wall, but not sharing dwelling walls.
Sepedi: Ntlo ye e dikaneditšwego le tše dingwe
Siswati: Indlu lesekhatsi kwesidlidli setindlu / Likhaya emkhatsini wemakhaya labiyelwe lutsango lunye / Inculumba
Tshivenda: Nnḓu ya tshigwadani / Nnḓu ire dzharaṱani nthihi na dziṅwe

English_Definition: Rooms that are used by several members of the household for common purposes or activities, e.g. eating, watching television or movies, sitting, etc.
IsiNdebele: Indawo yokuditjha ngendlini / Lindawo zomuntu woke ngekhaya
IsiXhosa: amagumbi asetyenziswa ngumntu wonke ohlala kuloo mzi
Tshivenda: Lufhera lwa muṱanganelwa / Lufhera lu shumiswaho nga miṱa minzhi

English_Definition: An entity to which the service is / would be delivered, and which receives one bill if the service is billed; alternatively known as a delivery point.
Tshivenda: Yuniti ya / Tshipiḓa tsha / Fhethu ha vhuṱanganedzatshumelo

English_Definition: A dwelling that has been destroyed.
A dwelling unit that has not been built completely.
Sepedi: Moraka / Bodulo bjoo bo sa agiwago / Letlema

English_Definition: A hut is one form of dwelling found mainly in non-urban (rural) areas, thus a round structure made of materials such as mud walls and thatch or grass roofs. Note: A hut may not necessarily be round; it may have any other shape.
Sepedi: Ngwako wa bjang / Ntlo ya bjang
Tshivenda: Nnḓu yo fhaṱiwaho nga mavu ya ṱhanga ya hatsi / ya mahayani / (sialala/mvelelo)

English_Definition: All structures other than buildings. Inclusions: Highways, streets, roads, bridges, etc.
One of two houses joined together with one common wall. Each house usually has its own private ground and has no other dwelling below or above it.
Sepedi: Ntlo ye e kgomaganego le ye nngwe

English_Definition: Dwellings or structures not privately occupied by a household but rather by individuals with one or more common characteristics. Compare institution. Note: Occupants are usually provided with communal meals served from a common kitchen. Other facilities such as bathrooms and laundries are also shared. These dwellings include institutions such as hospitals, prisons, homes for special-care citizens (e.g. aged, disabled, juvenile offenders, etc.), boarding schools and some workers' hostels.
Tshivenda: Vhudzulo ha tshipentshela / Vhudzulo ha ndivho nthihi

English_Definition: A traditional construction method whereby walls are built with wooden sticks / poles and covered with mud or a mixture of mud and clay.
Tshivenda: U fhaṱa nga basha na u nama

English_Definition: Use of body measurements, such as height and weight, to determine a person’s nutritional status.
Sepedi: Antherophometheriki / Kelo ya maemo a phepo
Sesotho: Tekolo ya phepo ho ya ka seemo

English_Definition: A survey conducted on the full set of observation objects belonging to a given population or universe.
A person that resides with the household for at least four nights a week. Note: Exclusions:  Domestic workers, unless they are paid in kind.  Children at boarding school.
IsiXhosa: amalungu ekhaya nachithe ubuncinci beentsuku ezine ngeveki belala kwelo khaya
Sesotho: Setho sa ntlong / Setho sa madulammoho

English_Definition: Two or more households living in the same dwelling unit.
If the household head is not available for an interview it is possible to speak to another responsible adult in the household.
Tshivenda: Mualuwa a re na vhuḓifhinduleli / Muthu muhulwane a re na vhuḓifhinduleli

English_Definition: The opening of the way, through legislation and a conductive environment, for everybody to gain access to opportunities that lead to some perceived benefits.

Afrikaans: Basiese Onderwys en Opleiding vir Volwassenes (BOOV)
English_Definition: All learning and training programmes for adults from levels 1 to 4, where ABET level 4 is equivalent to grade 9 in public schools, or a National Qualifications Framework level 1, as stipulated in the South African Qualifications Authority Act (Act 58 of 1995).
Sepedi: Thuto ya Motheo le Tlhahlo ya Batho ba Bagolo
Sesotho: Thuto ya Motheo le Kwetliso ya Batho ba Baholo
Tshivenda: Pfunzo ya mutheo na vhugudisi ha vhaaluwa
Xitsonga: Dyondzo ya Masungulo na Ndzetelo wa Lavakulu

English_Definition: Percentage of the population of a specific age enrolled, irrespective of the level of education.
Sepedi: Rešio ya boingwadišo ya mengwaga ye e itšego
Sesotho: Reshiyo ya ba ingodiseditseng ho ithuta ho ya ka dilemo
Siswati: Silinganiso selinani lekubhalisa kwebafundzi ngekweminyaka yebudzala
Tshivenda: Phimo ya u ṅwalisa ho sedzwa vhukale ho tewaho

English_Definition: Enrolled at and going regularly to any accredited educational institution (public or private) for organised learning at any level of education. Attendance can be full-time or part-time, and distance learning is included. Temporary absence, e.g. due to illness, does not interrupt attendance.
Nine years of schooling from grade 1 to grade 9.
The number of years or the age-span during which children and youth are legally obliged to attend school.
Sesotho: Thuto ya tlameho; thuto e tlamang

English_Definition: Percentage of the total enrolment at all levels to the total population.
Sesotho: Karolo ya baingodisi bohle; palo ya boingodiso bohle

English_Definition: Study by means of correspondence, telecommunication media or computer programmes. Courses are self-instructional and two-way communication takes place between student and the institution. Learners need not be on campus to attend classes but can continue their normal work programmes at home.

Learners who leave the education system without completing a given grade. The drop-out rate is calculated as a residual figure which is derived after the repetition and promotion rates are calculated. The drop-out rate in a particular grade for a particular year is calculated by simply deducting the repetition and promotion rate for that particular grade and year from 100%.
Sepedi: Reiti ya go tlogela sekolo/ Kelo ya balesasekolo
Tshivenda: Phimo ya u litsha tshikolo/ vhamoḓi

English_Definition: Any institution providing education. Inclusions: early childhood education, primary, secondary, further or higher education, institution providing specialised, vocational, adult, distance or community education.
Sesotho: Setsi / Setheo sa thuto / Institjushene ya thuto

English_Definition: Deprecated. Use highest level of education or educational attainment.
See highest level of education.
Any registered institution whose sole or main purpose is the provision of education, including preschool, tertiary, adult education, etc.
Sepedi: Lefelo la thuto/ insititušene ya thuto
Sesotho: Setsha se ngodisitsweng sa thuto; institjhushene ya thuto

English_Definition: Any person who teaches, educates or trains other persons or who provides professional educational services.
A learner who is registered at a school.
The act of officially being admitted to a programme of study.
Proportion of the population in a specified age group attending school to the total population in that age group.
Sesotho: Karolo ya baingodisi; palo ya boingodiso

English_Definition: The area of concentration of tertiary studies.
Sesotho: Lekala le ikgethileng la thuto; lekala la thuto

English_Definition: The education attained at an educational institution that follow a given approved curriculum.
Sesotho: Thuto ya mananeo a hlophisitsweng; thuto e hlophisitsweng

English_Definition: A stage of instruction usually covered in one school year.
Ratio of the enrolment in a specific class to the total enrolment at all levels.
IsiXhosa: Umlinganiselo wobhaliso lwebanga elithile /ireshiyo yobhaliso lwebanga elithile
Sepedi: Tekanyokelo ya boingwadišo kereiting ye e itšego
Sesotho: Karolo ya barutwana ho ya ka kereiti; palo ya boingodiso kereiting
Tshivenda: Ndivhanele ya kuṅwaliselendivhiswa kha murole / gireidi
Xitsonga: Mpimoxiave wa ntsariso wa giredi yo karhi

English_Definition: A student who has successfully completed all requirements of an educational programme and has been awarded a certificate of completion.
The total enrolment of pupils in a grade or cycle or level of education, regardless of age, expressed as percentage of the corresponding eligible official age-group population in a given school year.
Sesotho: Karolo ya barutwana ho ya ka dilemo; palo ya boingodiso bohle

English_Definition: All learning programmes leading to qualifications higher than grade 12 or its equivalent in terms of the National Qualifications Framework as contemplated in the South African Qualifications Authority Act, 1995 (Act No. 58 of 1995), including tertiary education as contemplated in schedule 4 of the Constitution.

Any institution that provides higher education on a full-time or part-time basis, and which is established or deemed to be established as a public higher education institution under the Higher Education Act, 1997; and declared as a public higher education institution under the Higher Education Act, 1997.
Sepedi: Setheo / Sehlongwa sa thuto ya godimo
Sesotho: Setheo sa thuto e phahemeng / Institjushene ya thuto e phahemeng
Xitsonga: Ndhawu ya dyondzo ya le henhla

English_Definition: The highest grade completed at school or the highest post-school qualification obtained. Synonym is educational attainment.
Xitsonga: Mfikelelo wa le henhla wa tidyondzo

English_Definition: A programme of education that a parent of a learner(s) may provide to his / her child at their own home. In addition a parent may, if necessary, enlist the specific services of a tutor for specific areas of the curriculum; or a legal independent form of education, alternative to attendance at a public or an independent school.
Learning that has been acquired outside a formal course of study taken at a post- secondary institution. Also expressed as non-formal or experiential learning.
Sepedi: Go ithuta mo e sego ga semmušo / Go ithuta go go sa elwego sekolong
Sesotho: Thuto ntle le ho kena sekolo
Tshivenda: U guda hu si ha fomaḽa/tshiofisi

English_Definition: The proportion of children, out of all children of admission age, who are coming to school for the first time.
Sesotho: Sekgahla sa ba qalang sekolo; palo ya ba qalang sekolong

English_Definition: The proportion of all admissions to Grade 1 that are over the official admission age (over 7 years).
Sepedi: Kelo ya ba go thoma morago
Sesotho: Sekgahla sa ba qalang ka morao ho nako; palo ya ba qalang ba le baholo
Xitsonga: Mpimo wa lava hundzeriweke hi nkarhi wo sungula xikolo

English_Definition: Any person receiving education or obliged to receive education in terms of the South African Schools Act, 1996 (Act No. 84 of 1996).
Total number of students enrolled in a given school divided by the total number of educators in the same school.
Sesotho: Karolelano ya barutwana ho ya ka matitjhere; palo ya baithuti ba matitjhere

English_Definition: The domains through which learners in the GET and FET bands experience a balanced curriculum. They serve as a sound basis for developing the learning programme to be implemented in schools. Eight learning areas were identified for GET and FET bands. Deprecated term is ‘subject’.
Ability to read and write with understanding in any language. A person is literate who can, with understanding, both read and write a short simple statement on his everyday life.
Sepedi: Tsebo ya go bala le go ngwala
Sesotho: Tsebo ya ho bala le ho ngola

English_Definition: The proportion of the population above 15 years of age who can write and read with understanding, usually expressed as a percentage of the total population above that age.
Sepedi: Kelo ya tsebo ya go bala le go ngwala
Sesotho: Sekgahla sa tsebo ya ho bala le ho ngola;palo ya ba tsebang ho ngola le ho bala
Xitsonga: Mpimo wa vuswikoti byo hlaya no tsala/mpimo wa literesi

English_Definition: The proportion of the population above 15 years of age who can write and read with understanding, expressed as a percentage of the total population of the same age.
Sepedi: Tekanyokelo ya tsebo ya go bala le go ngwala
Sesotho: Palo ya ba tsebang ho bala le ho ngola
Xitsonga: Mpimoxiave wa vuswikoti byo hlaya no tsala/mpimo xiave wa literesi

English_Definition: Non-formal education may take place both within and outside educational institutions, and may cater to persons of all ages. Depending on country contexts, it may cover educational programmes to impact adult literacy, basic education for out-of-school children, life-skills, work-skills, and general culture. Non-formal education programmes do not necessarily follow the ladder system, may have varying duration, and may or may not confer certification of the learning achieved.
Sepedi: Thuto ye e sego ya semmušo / Thuto ye e sa elwego ka sekolong
Sesotho: Thuto ntle le ho kena sekolo

English_Definition: A student who does not receive full-time tuition.
Tshivenda: Mutshudeni a sa funzwi tshifhinga tshoṱhe / Mutshudeni a sa dzheni tshikolo tshifhinga tshoṱhe

English_Definition: Percentage of learners promoted to the next grade in the following school year.
Total number of students enrolled in a given school divided by the total number of educators in the same school. Synonym is learner-educator ratio.
Sesotho: Karolelano ya barutwana ho ya ka matitjhere; palo ya baithuti ka titjhere

English_Definition: Successful completion of a level of education or organized course of study, usually denoted by the acquisition of a certificate, e.g. school-leaving certificate, diploma, degree or professional title.
A student who enrols in the same grade or year of study of the same educational programme for a second or further time.
The percentage of learners who are enrolled in the same grade in the current school year as in the previous school year.
Sesotho: Sekgahla sa ba phetang; palo ya ba phetang

English_Definition: A person attending primary or secondary school.

An educational institution or that part of such an institution at which education and training, including pre-primary education, is provided and which is maintained, managed and controlled or subsidised by a provincial education department, excluding a university and technikon.
A person attending a college, university or some other post-school educational institution, whether part-time or full-time.

The percentage of a learner cohort that enters together in the first grade of primary education and that reaches a given grade (e.g. Grade 5) or the final grade of an education cycle, either with or without repeating a grade. See drop-out rate.
IsiZulu: Izinga lokuqhubekela phambili/izinga labafike ebangeni elithile

English_Definition: Tokens to the equivalent of the free basic electricity that households are entitled to and for use in pre-paid electricity systems.
The general purpose Alternating Current (AC) electrical power supply.
A place where people or households bring recyclable products with the intention of selling them.
IsiXhosa: indawo ethenga izinto ezindala ezinokuphinda zisebenziseke
Siswati: Indzawo letsenga tintfo letingakhandvwa kabusha / letingentiwa busha / Engwendeni
Tshivenda: Senthara ya u renga zwithu zwo shumiswaho

English_Definition: Measures that are planned, implemented and controlled to avoid / alleviate the impact of human-originated pollution and natural disasters on biodiversity.
This includes golf courses, caravan parks, nature reserves, forest areas, state land, public entertainment areas, parks and botanical gardens.
Sepedi: Diphaka tša mmušo le mafelo a boitapološo
Tshivenda: Phakha dza muvhuso na fhethu ha vhuḓimvumvusi
Xitsonga: Phaka ya tiko na ndhawu ya vuhungaselo

English_Definition: The collection, treatment and disposal of waste.
Sesotho: Botsamaisi ba dilahlwa / Ho hlekwa ha matlakala

English_Definition: Sewerage system operations and waste water treatment.

Person recognized or nominated by the household as assuming the role of the household head in the absence of the usual household head. Note: this may be because the person recognized as the household head stays elsewhere for work purposes, or because he/she was not present on the reference night (census) or for the required period of time in the reference period (surveys).

The interval of time between the day, month and year of birth and the day and year of occurrence of the event expressed in the largest completed unit of solar time such as years for adults and children, and months, weeks, days, hours or minutes of life, as appropriate, for infants under one year of age.
Age expressed as the number of years lived by an individual; the person’s age at their last birthday. Age is also derived from the date of birth question and is the age at a person’s last birthday.
A person who receives accommodation and meals in someone else’s house in return for payment.
All those diseases, morbid conditions or injuries which either resulted in or contributed to death and the circumstances of the accident or violence which produced any such injuries.
A person under the age of 18 years.
One’s son or daughter.

All children born to a woman, whether in or out of marriage, whether born in a present or a previous marriage or union, and whether living or dead at the time of the census. Stillbirths (children born dead) are not included.
Sepedi: Bana ba ba belegilwego/bana ba thari

English_Definition: A branch of religion or faith group. For example, where religion is given as Christian, the denomination might be given as Methodist.

A physical or mental handicap which has lasted for six months or more, or is expected to last at least six months, which prevents the person from carrying out daily activities independently, or from participating fully in educational, economic or social activities. See handicap and impairment.
Marital status where a person’s marriage has been legally dissolved and he/she has not remarried.
Social distinction between males and females. See sex.

The process of identifying and classifying the roles of women and men in a given community, their relations, access to and control over resources and benefits. It also includes a systematic examination of the different impacts (potential and/or actual) of a development programme on women and men.

Constraints on the relationship between the person with a disability and the social and physical environment, for example, in the areas of education, occupation, information or communication. See impairment.
A baby who has not attained his/her first birthday.

Afrikaans: Taal wat die meeste in die huishouding gepraat word
English_Definition: The language most often used by the individual at home, whether or not they consider it their mother tongue.
English_Term: Language spoken most often in the household
Setswana: Puo e e buiwang thata mo gae

English_Definition: The last child born alive, whether still living or not.
Two persons who live together in the same household as a married couple but who are not married to each other; a cohabiting couple.
English_Term: Living together as a married couple

English_Definition: Personal status of each individual in relation to the marriage laws or customs of a country. Customary unions are now recognised as a legal marital status. Categories under marital status include single, married, living together as a married couple, divorced, separated and widowed.

The act, ceremony or process by which the legal relationship of husband and wife is constituted. Marriages are categorised in South Africa as civil, religious, or traditional/customary. A marriage that was solemnised as civil as well as in either of the other ways is categorised as civil.
Having a husband or wife. See marital status.
One of two people living together as a married couple. Relationship of each to the other in a cohabiting couple.

A group with common characteristics (in terms of descent and history), particularly in relation to how they were (or would have been) classified before the 1994 elections. The following categories are provided in the census: Black African, coloured, Indian or Asian, white, other.
Deprecated. Use population group.
Religious or spiritual belief or preference, or an affiliation with an organised group having specific religious or spiritual tenets.

Afrikaans: Van tafel en bed geskei [van tafel en bed geskeide ...]
English_Definition: Situation where a married couple have parted without divorcing, thus allowing for reuniting if they wish at some time in the future. This is not a legal marital status under South African law, and is therefore self-defined.

Situation where a married couple have entered a court or written agreement describing the terms under which they will live apart while remaining married. Legal separation is a possible step towards divorce, but also allows for the couple to reunite.
Biological distinction between males and females. See gender.
The ratio of the number of males to the number of females, usually expressed as a percentage.
Sesotho: Papiso ya bong; palo ya bong

English_Definition: Person who is not married or cohabiting. Compare single (legal). See marital status.
Xitsonga: Ku nga tekiwangi /ku nga tekangi (hi ntolovelo)

English_Definition: Person who has never been married. Compare single (common usage). See marital status.
Sesotho: Ya eso nyale/ nyalwe ho hang (ka molao); ya sa nyalang; ya sa nyalwang
Tshivenda: U sa vhuya wa dzhia / dzhiwa (mulayo)/malwa
Xitsonga: Ku nga si tshama u tekiwa/teka (xinawu)

English_Definition: Person visiting or staying with a household who is not a usual member of the household, that is, does not stay in the household four nights a week on average. Compare visitor under Tourism and migration.
Woman whose husband has died and who has not married again. See marital status.
Marital status of a person whose spouse has died and who has not married again. See widow and widower.
Man whose wife has died and who has not married again. See marital status.
Young person typically between the ages of 14 and 25 or 35. The exact age range must be specified in any analysis.
A document code for an enumerator’s summary book.
Hierarchical combination of elements that results in a unique identifier for a structure or land parcel. See primary address, secondary address, postal address.
An area that falls under a recognised jurisdiction, such as a magisterial district or a municipality. It is bounded by a legally defined line.
An area that falls under a recognized jurisdiction, such as magisterial district or a municipality. It is bounded by a legally defined line.
A public register showing details of ownership, tenure and value of individual parcels of land.

The spatial divisions into which the country is demarcated for the purpose of census enumeration, as well as to facilitate data processing and analysis. Note: It also provides the sampling frame for other surveys.
Sesotho: Palabatho ka dikarolo tsa naha; thutalefatshe ya palabatho

English_Definition: The process of dividing the land into enumeration areas, with clear boundaries and of a defined enumeration area type.
Sesotho: Ho ralla palo ya batho meedi; moedi, palabatho

English_Definition: The number of people per given area. See size and density of locality.
An area managed by a district municipality.
See district management area.
A number assigned to a private dwelling during listing.
See enumeration area.
The process of counting all the members of a given population and collecting demographic and other information about each person. See direct interview and self-enumeration.
The smallest geographical unit (piece of land) into which the country is divided for census or survey purposes. See enumeration area type.
A unique number given to an EA for the purpose of record-keeping and coding.
Sesotho: Nomoro ya sebaka sa ho bala
Tshivenda: Nomboro ya tshipiḓa / vhupo ha mbalavhathu
Xitsonga: Nomboro ya ndhawu ya nhlayelo wa vanhu

English_Definition: The classification of enumeration areas according to set criteria profiling land use and human settlement within the area. Note: Not to be confused with geography type, which is a broader classification.
Sesotho: Mofuta wa sebaka sa ho bala
Tshivenda: Lushaka lwa tshipiḓa / vhupo ha mbalavhathu

English_Definition: A person who visits households or individuals in a specific enumeration area for the purpose of administration of questionnaires or for self-enumeration.

A register of demarcation and listing information pertaining to a particular EA, known colloquially as the 09 book, which identifies an EA by province, local authority, main place name and subplace name, and by means of maps and/or aerial photographs. Used during enumeration to record key information such as visits or attempted visits, and total households and people counted.
Sesotho: Buka e kgutsufaditsweng ya mmalabatho; paka ya kgutsafatso ya mmadi

English_Definition: The sites and stand, yard, or plot described by cadastre on a map.
A unique 21-digit number assigned to an individual erf.
Plural of Erf.
Classification of structures as per main use.
A system or hardware, software and procedures designed to support the capturing, management , monitoring , manipulation, analysis, modeling and display of spatially referenced data.
Sesotho: Tlhophiso ya tjhabisetso ka lefatshe; tlhophiso ya tsebo ka lefatshe
Xitsonga: Sisiteme ya mahungu ya swa ntivomisava (SMN)

English_Definition: An approach whereby tariffs are set on an area with the assumption that consumers living in that area have the same socio-economic profile.
Classification according to settlement characteristics.
See density, population.
All collective living quarters other than hostels – one of ten geographical EA types. See enumeration area type. Compare institution (enumeration) under Housing and services.
A compilation of a register of all dwellings and other structures in a given Enumeration Area.
See, density, population.
Subdivision of the country for the administration of the judicial system as proclaimed by the Department of Justice.
First level of place names.
Category A municipality.
Sesotho: Mmasepala e moholo; sebaka sa mmasepala e moholo

English_Definition: The area of jurisdiction of the third sphere of government, after national and provincial.
The area of jurisdiction of the third sphere of government, after national and provincial.
Any area not classified as urban. See geography type. See also density, population.
Hierarchical combination of elements that results in a unique identifier for a structure or land parcel. See primary address, secondary address, and postal address.
The civic entities below the level of municipality in the census geography hierarchy. See main place and subplace.
A unique identifier for delivering post to an individual or organisation.
Physical address of a land parcel or structure.
Farms and traditional areas characterised by low population densities, low levels of economic activity and low levels of infrastructure.
Any area that is not classified urban. Rural areas may comprise one or more of the following: tribal areas, commercial farms and informal settlements. See settlement type.
A unique identifier for a sub-unit within a structure or land parcel.

The listing procedure used in informal settlements to sub-divide the area into smaller parts that are defined by boundaries such as footpaths, dirt / gravel roads etc., and other prominent land marks.
Tshivenda: U kanula mikhukhuni/mishashani / Nḓila ya u vhea mikano mikhukhuni/ mishashani

English_Definition: Deprecated. Use geography type.
A classification of geographical areas into high density or large settlement, and low density. Note: This variable provides an alternative basis of analysis to the urban/rural classification.
A hand-drawn map of an area. Note: Sketch maps do not possess the high order of accuracy contained in topographic maps.
Sepedi: Mmepe wa go thalwa ka seatla
Tshivenda: Mepe wa tshiketshe/wo ṅwalwaho nga tshanḓa

English_Definition: A piece of land smaller than a farm used for cultivation of vegetables or the breeding of animals.
IsiNdebele: Umtlayo wokutjala / Wokufuya Isikhekhe sokutjala / Sokufuya

English_Definition: A person attending a college, university or some other post-school educational institution, whether part-time or full-time.
Second (lowest) level of place names. See main place.
Areas within a town or city proclaimed or set aside mainly for residing purposes. See informal settlement and subplace.
An area proclaimed as such by a local authority profiling a specific land use unique to urban functions.
An area proclaimed as such by a local authority profiling a specific land use unique to urban functions.
Communally owned land under the jurisdiction of a traditional leader.
Deprecated. Use traditional area.
An area that is legally proclaimed to be under tribal authorities.
Sepedi: Madulo a taolo ya kgoši / Metseselegae
Tshivenda: Vhupo ha khosi/kusi / Muvhundu ure fhasi ha khosi

English_Definition: See unit identifier.
A unique number for each structure on a land parcel, e.g. number assigned by the local authority or a service provider.
Formal cities and towns characterised by higher population densities, high levels of economic activities and high levels of infrastructure.

A continuously built-up area with characteristics such as type of economic activity and land use. Cities, towns, townships, suburbs, etc. are typical urban areas. An urban area is one which was proclaimed as such (i.e. in an urban municipality under the old demarcation) or classified as such during census demarcation by the Geography department of Stats SA based on their observation of the aerial photographs or on other information. See settlement type and EA type.

Urban settlements (formal) occur on land that has been proclaimed as residential. A formal urban settlement is usually structured and organised. Plots or erven make up a formal and permanent arrangement. A local council or district council controls development in these areas. Services such as water, sewage, electricity and refuse removal are provided; roads are formally planned and maintained by the council. This includes suburbs and townships.

Urban informal settlements, or 'squatter camps', are usually located in urban areas. The dwelling units in informal settlements are usually made of materials such as zinc, mud, wood, plastics, etc. They are typically disorderly and congested and are sometimes referred to as squatter settlements.
Sesotho: Bodulo ba toropo (bo seng molaong) / Mekhukhu

English_Definition: Land not currently being used.
IsiXhosa: umhlaba ongasetyenziswanga/ umhlaba ekungekho mntu kuwo
Sepedi: Naga ye e sa šomišwego / Molala

English_Definition: A settlement located within a traditional area.

A communal living quarter for workers, provided by a public organisation such as a local authority, or a private organisation such as a mining company. These were residential dormitories established for migrant workers during the apartheid era, and they continue to house people working in certain industries, such as the mining industry.
The number of live births in a given year per 1 000 women or per woman in each childbearing age group from 15– 19 up to 45–49.
Sepedi: Monono wa nywaga ye itšego/maamušo a nywaga ye itšego
Setswana: Dingwaga tse di totilweng tsa loumo

English_Definition: Weight within the first hour of life before a significant postnatal weight loss has occurred.
Setswana: Boima (ba lesea) ka nako ya pelego

English_Definition: A statistical measure of the weight of a person scaled according to height, used to estimate if a person is underweight or overweight.
Sesotho: Palo ya kakanyo ya boima ba mmele

English_Definition: Deaths per 1 000 children that survive to their first birthday. See infant mortality, child mortality, neonatal mortality, post-neonatal mortality, and under-five mortality.
Xitsonga: Nhlayo ya ku fa ka vana

English_Definition: Morbid conditions, if any, giving rise to the immediate cause of death.
Xitsonga: Leswi nga na xiave eka swivangelo swa rifu

English_Definition: The number of live births observed in a population over a given period relative to the size of the population as estimated at the middle of that time period. The rate is usually stated per 1 000 and the most usual period is one year.

The number of deaths in a year per 1 000 mid-year population of a specific year. It is the ratio of the annual number of deaths occurring to the number exposed to the risk of dying during the reference period.
Births occurring in a specific year and registered within the same year.
Sesotho: Tswalo ya ba phelang ha jwale
Setswana: Masea a a tshotsweng a tshela gajaana
Tshivenda: Mabebo a khanḓwa / tshetshe / tshie dzi tshilaho a tshifhingatehwa
Xitsonga: Ntswalo wa lava hanyaka wa sweswi

English_Definition: Is a principal event and is the disappearance of life at any time after birth has taken place.
The childbearing status of women, couples, groups or the population (only live births).
See Human immunodeficiency virus.

The pathogenic organism responsible for acquired Immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), formally or also known as lymphadenopathy virus (LAV), the name given by the Montagnier Et al. in 1983, or the human T-cells lymphrotropic virus type III (HTLV-III), the name given by Gallo et al. to the virus reported in 1984.
Sepedi: Baerase ye e fokotšago mašole a mmele
Sesotho: Kwatsi (HIV); vaerase e bolayang masole a mmele

English_Definition: The disease or condition directly leading to death.
Sepedi: Lebaka la ka pejana la go hlola lehu

English_Definition: See neonatal mortality, post-neonatal mortality, under-five mortality and child mortality. All rates are expressed as deaths per 1 000 live births, except child mortality, which is expressed as deaths per 1 000 children surviving to the first birthday.
Sepedi: Dikelo tša mahu a masea le bana
Sesotho: Sekgahla sa ho shwa ha masea le bana
Tshivenda: Zwikalampfu dza khanḓwa / tshetshe/ tshie na vhana
Xitsonga: Mipimo ya mafu ya ticece na vana

English_Definition: Number of deaths of children under one year occurring in the same year.
A type of malnutrition caused by insufficient protein consumption.
Births occurring in a given calendar year but recorded in subsequent calendar years.
The most frequent underlying cause of death in any given population.
Sepedi: Tlholoketapele ye e bataletšego/bobamego ya lehu
Sesotho: Sesosa se itlhommeng pele sa lefu

English_Definition: An estimate of the average number of additional years a person could expect to live if the age-specific death rates for a given year prevailed for the rest of his/her life. This can be derived for either males or females and is, in most populations, slightly higher for females. Life expectancy is normally determined at birth but can be derived at any other age based on the current death rates.

The complete expulsion or extraction from its mother’s womb of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of the pregnancy, which after such separation, breathes or shows any other evidence of life.
Sepedi: Masea a go belegwa a phela

English_Definition: A medical condition caused by an improper or inadequate diet or nutrition. See kwashiorkor / wasting; marasmus, stunting.
A form of severe protein-energy malnutrition characterised by energy deficiency.
IsiXhosa: isifo sokungondleki esibangelwa kukusilela kweeproteni emzimbeni
Tshivenda: Marasimusi/u shaya pfushi dzi wanalaho kha phurotheini

English_Definition: Number of female deaths that occurred during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy because of any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.
Sepedi: Kelo ya mahu a batswetši/kelo ya mahu a babelegi
Sesotho: Sekgahla sa ho shwa ha bomme ka lebaka la pelehi
Xitsonga: Mpimo wa ku fa ka vayimani

English_Definition: The number of women who die as a result of complications of pregnancy or childbearing in a given year per 100 000 live births in that year.
Sepedi: Tekanyokelo ya mahu a batswetši/tekanyokelo ya mahu a babelegi
Sesotho: Karolo ya mafu a pelehi ho bomme;palo ya bomme ba shwang ka lebaka la pelehi
Tshivenda: Ndivhanele ya mpfu dza zwikole / vhaimana

English_Definition: All morbid conditions, diseases and injuries entered on the death certificate. Note: These include those involved in the morbid train of events leading to the death which were classified as either the underlying cause, the intermediate cause, or any intervening cause and those conditions which contributed to death but were not related to the disease or condition causing death.
Sepedi: Mabaka a mantši a go hlola mahu

English_Definition: Number of deaths occurring to children under 28 days.
Sepedi: Mahu a masea pele a fetša kgwedi
Sesotho: Mafu a masea a ka tlase ho kgwedi; mafu a masea a mafubedu
Setswana: Dintsho tsa masea a a ka fa tlase ga kgwedi
Tshivenda: Mpfu dza khanḓwa / tshetshe / tshie nṋu

English_Definition: Number of deaths occurring between 28 days and less than one year.
Sepedi: Mahu a masea a ka godimo ga kgwedi
Sesotho: Mafu a masea a ka hodimo ho kgwedi
Setswana: Dintsho tsa masea a a fetileng kgwedi

English_Definition: The death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the cause of death.
IsiXhosa: Ukufa okungqamene nokukhulelwa/ nokumitha/ nokuba nzima
Sepedi: Mahu a go amana le boimana
Sesotho: Mafu a bakwang ke boimana; ho shwa ho amanang le boimana
Setswana: Loso lo lo amanang le boimana

English_Definition: The number of births recorded (registered) in a specific year, irrespective of when the birth actually occurred. The births recorded in any given year include the births that occurred during that year plus other births that occurred in years prior to the year of registration. It should be noted that not all births are recorded (registered).
Sepedi: Matswalo a a ngwadišitšwego a baphedi/masea
Sesotho: Ngodiso ya ba tswetsweng ba phela
Setswana: Pelego e e kwadisitsweng ya masea
Siswati: Lababhalisiwe labatelwe baphila / lubhaliso lwalabatelwe baphila

English_Definition: Intra-uterine death of a foetus of at least 26 weeks of gestation that showed no sign of life after complete birth.
Sesotho: Ba hlahileng ba kgathetse; ya tswetsweng a shwele

English_Definition: A condition where a child’s height is too low for his / her age.
The proportion of persons in a specified group (age, sex, or health status) alive at the beginning of an interval (such as a 5-year period) who survive to the end of the interval.
An indicator that measures the number of children with or without parents. However, for policy purposes, children without parents are normally considered.

Average number of children born alive to a woman during her lifetime if she were to bear children at each age in accordance with the prevailing age-specific fertility rates. It is obtained by summing up all age-specific fertility rates for each year of the childbearing span.
The probability of dying between birth and the fifth birthday.
Sepedi: Mahu a bana ba ka tlase ga mengwaga ye mehlano
Sesotho: Ho shwa ha ba ka tlase ho dilemo tse hlano
Setswana: Dintsho tsa ba ba ka fa tlase ga dingwaga tse tlhano
Tshivenda: Mpfu dza vha fhasi ha miṅwaha miṱanu
Xitsonga: Ku fa ehansi ka ntlhanu wa malembe

English_Definition: The disease or injury that initiated the train of events leading to death; or the circumstances of the accident or violence that produced the fatal injury.
Sepedi: Lebaka le le bobamego la go hlola lehu

English_Definition: A condition where a child’s weight is too low for his / her height.

Expenditure on goods and services acquired, and privately used by household members, including imputed values for items produced and consumed by the household itself. See non-consumption expenditure. See also durable, semi-durable and non-durable goods.

Household items that last for a long time, such as kitchen appliances, computers, radios and televisions, cars and furniture, usually acquired once in several years. Compare semi- durable goods and non-durable goods.
Sepedi: Dithoto tša go kgotlelela/diphahlo tša go kgotlelela/tšea lebaka le le telele
Tshivenda: Thundu dza ndalamo/thundu dza ndeme khulwane

English_Definition: Assets belonging to a household.
An economic activity carried out by members of a household at the same physical address, e.g. backyard chicken-rearing, handcrafts, etc.
Amount spent by the household in the reference peried in cash, kind or through barter, consisting of consumption and non-concumption expenditure.

All receipts by all members of a household, in cash and in kind, in exchange for employment, or in return for capital investment, or receipts obtained from other sources such as pension, etc. Compare household income (census).
Expenditure on items such as taxes, and remittances and contributions to members of other households.
Setswana: Ditshenyegelo tse e seng tsa dijego

English_Definition: Household items that do not last long, for example food, and personal care items. Households acquire these items on a daily, weekly or monthly basis. See durable goods and semi-durable goods.
Sepedi: Dithoto tša go se kgotlelele/dithoto tša go se tšee lebaka le le telele
Setswana: Dithoto tse di sa tshwareleleng; majaja

English_Definition: Household items that last longer than non-durable goods but still need replacing more often than durable goods. Example: clothing, shoes, material for clothing.
Sesotho: Thepa e tswarellang nako e teletsana
Tshivenda: Thundu dza ndalamozwayo/ thundu dza ndeme zwayo

English_Definition: A structure, usually multi-storey, consisting of a number of dwellings sharing the same residential address, and usually sharing a common entrance, foyer or staircase. See flat.
Built structure with a roof and walls.

Premises originally intended for the temporary accommodation of persons with common activities or interests, e.g. military camps, refugee camps and camps established for the housing of workers in mining, agriculture, public works or other types of enterprises.

1. Structurally separate and independent places of abode intended for habitation by large groups of individuals or several households. Such quarters usually have certain common facilities, such as cooking and ablution facilities, lounges or dormitories, which are shared by the occupants. Collective living quarters may be further classified into hotels, rooming houses and other lodging houses, institutions and camps. 2. Living quarters where certain facilities are shared by groups of individuals or households. They can be divided into: (a) hotels, motels, guest houses, etc.; (b) workers’ hostels and student residences; and (c) institutions.
English_Term: Collective living quarters / communal living quarters

English_Definition: Hostel where the accommodation has been converted into self-contained units for households. See workers’ hostel.
Physical structure on the same erf/plot as main property intended as living quarters for a domestic worker.
Sepedi: Kotase ya mošomi wa ka lapeng
Setswana: Bonno ba modiri/mothusi wa mo gae; dikotase tsa modiri/mothusi wa mo gae
Xitsonga: Vutshamo bya mutirhi wa le kaya

English_Definition: See dwelling unit.
Any structure intended or used for human habitation. Synonym is living quarters.
See informal dwelling.
Sepedi: Bodulo bja go se be bja semolao
Xitsonga: Vutshamo, byo ka byi nga ri bya ximfumo

English_Definition: A dwelling made primarily of clay, mud, reeds or other locally available natural materials. Such dwellings can be found as single units or in clusters.

Structure or part of a structure or group of structures occupied or meant to be occupied by one or more than one household. Includes structure or part of a structure which is vacant and/or under construction, but can be lived in at the time of the survey. Includes units in collective living quarters, unlike a housing unit. Dwelling units may therefore comprise housing units plus units in collective living quarters when applicable.
A dwelling whose inhabitants are absent at the time of the visit or during the reference period during a census or survey.
Sepedi: Bodulo bja go se be le motho
Setswana: Bonno, bo bo se nang ope
Tshivenda: Vhudzulo vhu si na muthu / ndi mahagala
Xitsonga: Vutshamo, vinyi va nga ri kona

English_Definition: A dwelling that is uninhabited, i.e. no one lives there.
Sepedi: Bodulo bja go se dulwe ke motho
Xitsonga: Vutshamo, byo ka byi nga tshamiwi hi munhu

Afrikaans: Elektrisiteit vir kook-, verhittings- en/of verligtingsdoeleindes
English_Definition: Electricity from the public supplier.
English_Term: Electricity for cooking, heating and/or lighting
IsiXhosa: Umbane wokupheka, ukufudumeza kunye okanye ukukhanyisa
Sepedi: Mohlagase wa go apea, go ruthetša le/ goba go bonega
Sesotho: Motlakase o phehang, futhumatsang le/kapa o kgantshang
Setswana: Motlakase wa go apaya, go thuthafatsa le/kgotsa go bonesa/bonega
Tshivenda: Muḓagasinḓisedzwa (wa u bika, u dudedza, u funga)
Xitsonga: Gezi ro sweka, ro hisisa na/ kumbe ku lumeka

English_Definition: An undertaking concerned with the generation or transmission and distribution of electricity, including electrical power installations, which as subsidiary divisions of undertakings produce electricity for regular use by these undertakings.
A dwelling, usually on one floor, with at least one wall shared with another such dwelling, within a block of flats. Synonym is apartment. See also block of flats.

A structure built according to approved plans, i.e house on separate stands, flat or apartment, townhouse, room in a backyard, rooms or flatlets elsewhere contrasted with informal dwelling and traditional dwelling.
An amount of electricity determined by government that should be provided free to poor households to meet basic needs, currently set at 50 kWh per month per household.
IsiZulu: Isabelo sikagesi samahhala; ugesi ophakelwa mahhala
Tshivenda: Muḓagasiphiṅwa tshayambadelo/muḓagasi wa mutheo wa mahala

English_Definition: An amount of water determined by government that should be provided free to poor households to meet basic needs, currently set at 6 kl per month per household within 200 metres from each dwelling.
IsiZulu: Isabelo samanzi samahhala; amanzi aphakelwa mahhala
Tshivenda: Maḓiphiṅwa tshayambadelo/maḓi a mutheo a mahala

English_Definition: A collective form of accommodation for workers or students, but not including boarding school hostels. See workers’ hostel.
An establishment providing accommodation and meals for pay. See collective living quarters, tourist hotel and residential hotel.
A freestanding dwelling.

A unit of accommodation for a household, which may consist of one structure, or more than one structure, or part of a structure. (Examples of each are a house, a group of rondavels, and a flat.) It may be vacant, or occupied by one or more than one household. A housing unit usually has a separate entrance from outside or from a common space, as in a block of flats. See dwelling unit, living quarters and collective living quarters.
Flush toilet, chemical toilet or pit latrine with ventilation pipe.
Sepedi: Setlabakelo sa go hlweka sa botshwelamare/ thoilete
Sesotho: Maranrang a tlhwekiso ya ntlwana; matlwana a hlwekileng

Afrikaans: Indeks van fisiese volume van elektrisiteitsproduksie (Maatskaplike Statistieke)
English_Definition: A statistical measure of the change in the volume of production of electricity in a given period and the volume of production of electricity in the base period.
English_Term: Index of physical volume of electricity production (Social Statistics)
Sepedi: Kelotšhupetšo ya boleng bjo bo bonalago bja tšweletšo ya mohlagase
Sesotho: Tshupane ya bongata ba tlhahiso ya motlakase
Xitsonga: Xikombo xa vholumumbonakalo ya andziso wa gezi (tinhlayohlayo ta vanhu)

English_Definition: A makeshift structure not erected according to approved architectural plans, for example shacks or shanties in informal settlements or in backyards.
Sepedi: Ntlo ya go se be ya semolao
Xitsonga: Vutshamo byo ka byi nga ri bya ximfumo

English_Definition: An unplanned settlement on land that has not been surveyed or proclaimed as residential, consisting mainly of informal dwellings (shacks).
Sepedi: Madulo a go se be a semolao

English_Definition: Communal place of residence for people with a common characteristic, such as a hospital, school hostel, prison, defence force barracks or convent.
A room equipped for the preparation of principal meals and intended for that purpose.

A general term meaning the place where people stay. Living quarters can be divided into two main groups: housing units and collective living quarters. See also the diagram of types of living quarters in Appendix A.
A building where the major part of the floor space is not intended for dwelling but for other purposes such as commercial or industrial.
IsiZulu: Isakhiwo okungesona esokuhlala/ isakhiwo esingasetshenziselwa ukuhlala
Sepedi: Moago wa go se be wa madulo
Setswana: Moago/kago o/e e seng wa/ya bonno
Xitsonga: Muako lowu nga endleriwangiki ku tshama vanhu

Afrikaans: Aangelegde water in woning of op perseel
English_Definition: Piped water inside the household’s own dwelling or in their yard. It excludes water from a neighbour’s tap or a public tap that is not on site.
English_Term: Piped water in dwelling or on site
IsiXhosa: Amanzi asemibhobheni kwindawo yokuhlala okanye esizeni
Sepedi: Meetse a pompi ka gae goba setsheng
Sesotho: Metsi a pompo bodulong kapa setsheng
Setswana: Metsi a thepe mo ntlong kgotsa mo setsheng
Xitsonga: Mati ya pompi eka vutshamo kumbe ndhawu

English_Definition: Payment for use of property of another as living quarters.
Hotel providing semi-permanent accommodation. See tourist hotel.

Space in a housing unit or other living quarters enclosed by walls reaching from the floor to the ceiling or roof covering, or to a height of at least two metres, of an area large enough to hold a bed for an adult, that is, at least four square metres.
Principles and practices relating to the collection, removal or disposal of human excreta, household waste water and refuse, as they impact upon people and the environment.
One of two houses joined together with one common wall. Each house usually has its own private ground and has no other dwelling below or above it.
See dwelling, informal.
See informal settlement.
See erf.
Person who occupies a housing unit which is not his/her property and who pays (in money or in kind) for using the unit as living quarters for his/her household.
Arrangement under which a household occupies its dwelling.
Installation or system for the disposal of human excreta.
Installation or system for the disposal of human excreta.
A hotel providing accommodation to short-term residents, e.g. tourists or other travellers such as business people. See residential hotel.
A self-contained dwelling with private grounds within a common ground for other dwellings.
A dwelling made of clay, mud, reeds or other locally available materials. Note: This is a general term that includes huts, rondavels, etc. Such dwellings can be found as single units or in clusters.
One unit of electricity is equal to 1 kilowatt-hour (kWh). One gigawatt-hour (gWh) of electricity is equal to one million kilowatt-hours.
A stand, fenced or unfenced, which has no observable structure erected on it.
Sepedi: Setsha/setene sa go se be le moago

English_Definition: A communal living quarter for workers, provided by a public organisation such as a local authority, or a private organisation such as a mining company. These were residential dormitories established for migrant workers during the apartheid era, and they continue to house people working in certain industries, such as the mining industry.
Tshivenda: Hositele ya vhashumi (mbalombalo / zwitatisitika zwa matshilisano)

English_Definition: To use or utilise services, spend money or eat or drink food.
Tshivenda: U shumisa / U ḽa / U renga

English_Definition: An item received by the household from people who are not members of the household or items given away by members of the household to non-members, without compensation.
The act of spending or disbursing money.
Tshivenda: U shumisa kana u kovhekanya tshelede

English_Definition: A statement by a person/debtor in which he admits that he owes money to an individual or a company or a bank.
Sepedi: Kamogelo ya sekoloto/ go dumela sekoloto

English_Definition: Extensions to existing buildings as well as internal and external alterations of existing buildings.
A statement of charges for a service rendered or for the amount owed.
A decision taken in a civil matter or a dispute between two people or parties.
Notice to appear before the court of law where a dispute between two parties or people has to be heard, i.e. not for a criminal offence.
Cleaning using own staff or cleaning using subcontractors.
Occurs when the affairs of a company or close corporation are wound up by order of the court.
Sepedi: Tswalelo ya kgwebo ka kgapeletšo; phedišo ya kgwebo ya kgapeletšo
Sesotho: Taelo ya kgotla ya kgapo ya thepa; kgapo e tlamang
Setswana: Tswalokgwebo ka pateletso; phatlhalatsokgwebo ka pateletso
